reviewText: This is the last of this story arc, with the man calling himself the Eagle getting himself killed in the final story.  Of course it isn't over and done with, as we will see in Season Two (whenever it is released to us).  If I have any complaint about these episodes, the plot threads sometimes seem too simplistic and cliched for dealings with a criminal mastermind with truly enormous plans. The big shootout at the end was a contrivance belonging to TV westerns of the 50's, and as such seemed unsatisfactory to me.  Admittedly, this was a kid's action series.  But what comes off best are the developement of the central heroes of the series.  Diego (presumably a young man in his early 20's) becomes a little more human, and the hero-sidekick relationship between him and Bernardo, which started in the 4th DVD, begins to develope quite nicely. The sitcom elements that were always present seem more on the surface.  Fun to watch, like the others.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I remember "Zorro" very well and I enjoyed it very much.  I think that $249 is too much to pay for it.  So, I must remain "Zorro"... less, until and if they lower the price to something that is not so daunting.

reviewText: Anybody who has seen this show knows it is GREAT!! I'd love to get all of them (and hopefully I will) but they are so expensive. And for a poor boy on a budget well... which is why I was so happy to find the three I did for the price I did!!!!!!!!! I say if you can afford Walt Disney's Zorro at any price then I say grab them, you WON"T regret it!
Title: N/A

reviewText: The final volume of Season One begins to wind up the storyline of the Eagle.It has been a real pleasure to watch Zorro again and in color - though I admit I feel the original Black & White is far superior and suits the series better and in the 'Treasures' editions you see the series in its complete original form. But as I have said before - if you are a collector of anything Disney - hey why not treat yourself to both!The DVD quality is far from perfect in these color editions - perhaps Disney didn't expect much popularity in their movie club releases (yeah right!)This is common with most of their releases aimed at their Movie Club audience... grainy reproductions; poorly remastered editions in some cases and even poor editing. But the stories will always outweigh any limited faults in quality. This is so sad because every Disney production is a Treasure and collectors long to see TV episodes and movies as originally envisioned and with the reproduction advances available today with DVD - every new release should be given the 'Full Treatment'.Still I believe Disney are well aware that in whatever condition they release their product - people will buy it - just to rekindle fond memories of those long ago days and the opportunity to see again truly momentous classic movies & television - the like that will never come again! When they hold the keys to that great Vault, we are at their mercy!!!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I had been dying to find out what the story of "The Eagle" was (which I had one of the stories in comic book form) for years. I was not displeased. Usually I object to colorization, but the work done on this series is excellent. Happy to have access to the TV series after all these years.
